item.title: Article: 7 Clues that your business growth depends on your personal growth
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
There is no such thing as standing still in business, if you aren’t moving ahead you’re moving backwards; and there is only one way to make sure you keep moving forward and that is to make a conscious decision to do it. The difference between people who run successful businesses and those who do not is the degree to which they are willing to push themselves to grow personally. Successful entrepreneurs work as hard on themselves as they do on their business. They understand the most fundamental factor in business success: A business can only grow and be as successful as the quality of the thinking of the business owner. So here are 7 clues that you may need to look inward, at yourself, and consider your need for personal growth:

Anger

You find yourself getting angry more often than in the past. In the uncertain world of business ownership our triggers are pulled more often; understanding this is a key aspect of growth.

Stress

There are very few people who live a stress-free life, but as a business owner you are likely to experience more and more stress as the pressures of getting a business off the ground build up.

Frustration

Frustration is the feeling you get when you can’t achieve what you want. If you don’t possess the inner resourcefulness to cope, then frustration will be a bi-product.

Control

The irony of control is that the more you try and exert control, the more it slips through your fingers. Learning to influence, and to be flexible enough to be influenced, without the need to control, is key.

I’m Right

Feeling you have to be right all the time is indicative of an inability to be challenged. Being “right” is a seriously limiting approach to life, preventing you from learning from others and impeding growth that comes from seeing more of what life has to offer.

Denial

Denial stops you seeing the limitations within yourself that hold you back. Einstein said: “It is only when we can accept our limitations that we go beyond them.” Denial prevents growth because it closes the mind to the possibility of change and the concepts of new and more.

Ambition and Desire

We are taught from an early age to put our personal desires and ambitions second; we are taught to think of others first. The reality is that we can only serve others when we are serving our own desires and ambitions. You will never fulfil your potential in life if you deny your desires and ambition.

About the author

Dene is the founder of I Want To Be, a personal development consultancy that specialises in helping business owners develop themselves so that they can grow their business. Dene has over 30 years' commercial, leadership and management experience, having held a number of director roles, and he has also founded a number of his own businesses. His first book, ResourcefulMe,  investigates the subject of resourcefulness in the workplace.

item.title: Article: R.A.I.S.E. your game for better results
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Running a business is very simply about investing time and money; and if you get more back than you put in then you have a successful business. It is all about getting RESULTS. But have you ever thought about what it is that is bringing you the results you are currently achieving? If you haven’t then you are not in a position to do anything about them. One of the biggest problems for small and new businesses is sustaining them. According to various studies, a third of new businesses will have failed within 3 years, and more than a half won’t survive 5 years. Understanding what is bringing your results is key to long term success. There is a simple formula you can use to help you:

R = A x I x S x E

R stands for Results.

Step 1 is being consciously aware of the results you want to achieve. This is more than simply a business plan - it governs every part of how you run your business. From how you show up with clients, suppliers, partners, in fact anyone you work with, to the detail of the products and services that you offer and the prices you charge. Without absolute clarity in this area you cannot take actions that will ENSURE you achieve the results you want.

A stands for Attitude.

In business you will have both successes and failures on a daily basis. It is your attitude to these events that determines the next actions that you take - but most people are not consciously aware of how they react to success and failure. From this lack consciousness comes lack of awareness of...

I stands for Impact.

You impact every aspect of the world in which you live. Every action and reaction you have to every event impacts the people around you. Too often we see business people portrayed as aggressive and impatient. But truly successful business people have the ability to build effective teams of people who are motivated to achieve results. You can only achieve this by being aware of the impact that you have on people.

S stands for Skills.

In your business you will have jobs that you like doing and jobs that you don’t like doing. The key skill for any business owner is knowing which jobs are priorities and making sure that they can be done effectively and efficiently. The successful business owner knows that they cannot be good at all the things that need doing and they will need to assemble a team who have complementary skills.

E stands for energy.

It will all be for nothing if you don’t have the energy and stamina to get everything done and deal with the challenges of running a business. Physical fitness is important, but 90% of how energetic you feel is mental. There is an old adage:“ Your mind will quit a thousand times before your body will” Understanding how to manage your energy is the equivalent of making sure that you don’t run out of petrol on your journey. So now when you think you need to RAISE your game, you know the steps that you have to take.

About the author

Dene is the founder of I Want To Be, a personal development consultancy that specialises in helping business owners develop themselves so that they can grow their business. Dene has over 30 years' commercial, leadership and management experience, having held a number of director roles, and he has also founded a number of his own businesses. His first book, ResourcefulMe,  investigates the subject of resourcefulness in the workplace.

item.title: Expert interview: How to develop instant rapport
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Being able to quickly establish rapport with people you meet is an essential skill. According to Wikipedia, rapport is:
... a close and harmonious relationship in which the people or groups concerned understand each other's feelings or ideas and communicate well. The word stems from the old French verb rapporter which means literally to carry something back; and, in the sense of how people relate to each other means that what one person sends out the other sends back. For example, they may realize that they share similar values, beliefs, knowledge, or behaviours around politics, music or sports.
Rapport is something that is hard to define but we know when we have it, and we can really feel it when we lose rapport. It's easy to develop rapport with people we know or people who are like us and share the same interests and values, but how do we establish rapport and trust with people that are totally different to us? In this recording, BizClub's Richard White interviews top NLP trainers Julie French and Tony Burgess of the Acacemy of High Achievers  who provide excellent insights into how to quickly generate deeper levels of rapport. They cover how to build instant rapport both in person and on the telephone. A must listen to anyone who feels awkward with some prospects and clients.   [audio mp3="http://hzhapr15a.dmclub.net/personaldevelopment/wp-content/uploads/sites/6/2015/03/juliefrench3.mp3"][/audio] To download - right click here as select 'Save As'

About Julie French and Tony Burgess

Julie French and Tony Burgess are both founders of The Academy of High Achievers, a personal development business specialising in Neuro Linguistic Programming. Julie is an outstanding Executive Coach, Master Practitioner and Certified Trainer in Neuro Linguistic Programming (NLP), a Certified Trainer in 'Everything DiSC' and is also a Certified Professional Speaker and Firewalk instructor. Combining exceptional listening skills with a creative and empowering approach, Julie assists organisations and individuals to realise their vision. Tony has a degree in psychology, and for the last fourteen years he has specialised in helping people to thrive in their endeavours by teaching them powerful 'mental fitness' techniques and offering them super-effective connection and communication tools. He has worked with business leaders, teams within organisations, entrepreneurs, educators, students, sports people and members of the public to help them to tap into and release the full potential of their personal resources, preparing them to attain whatever outcomes they set out to achieve and much more besides.

item.title: Personal Development
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the Personal Development BizClub interest area. Our mission is to help you and your team develop the skills and mindset to achieve your business goals.

Through a combination of articles, seminars, clinics, and masterclasses we will be covering the following subject areas:

Personal growth

Helping you to become more resourceful and able to cope with the stresses and demands of a growing business.

Leadership skills

Developing your ability to lead a growing team and delegate effectively.

Relationship skills

Helping you and your team to develop their ability to develop relationships with customers, suppliers and other staff members

Communication skills

Helping you and your team to better communicate with each other, with customers and other stakeholders.

Personal effectiveness

Helping you and your team to set goals, prioritise, and get more done in less time.

item.title: Article: Time to recognise your emotional Intelligence
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
It is now widely recognised that Emotional Intelligence (EQ) is a better predictor of business success than traditional IQ. Most of the major American business schools now require their applicants to undertake EQ tests as well as IQ tests. This is because EQ is an indicator of how you get on with people and your ability to manage relationships. It is well established in large corporations but it is smaller businesses which can derive greater benefit from EQ. People issues show up far more quickly and with greater significance in smaller businesses. There is no hiding place in a smaller business and little spare capacity to cope with an employee who isn’t performing or a difficult client. Being a business owner is like being the captain of a boat. The speed at which you drive your boat is down to you and your comfort level. Whether you are a barge meandering along the canal or a speedboat skimming across the surface is your choice. Emotional Intelligence is simply the ability to look over your shoulder and see what is going on in the wake you leave behind. Your customers and employees are like water skiers attached to the back of your business boat. If you aren’t going fast enough they can’t get the momentum to get out of the water and if you are going too fast they can’t stay upright and deal with the wake you create. Emotionally intelligent business owners ask the right (difficult) questions: Do you have the ability to drive the boat at the speed needed to keep everything and everyone moving forward and on course? Does your team have the ability to stay upright as you drive the boat faster? Do you have the ability to attract the right talent for the team you want behind you? The answers to these questions (and many more) lie in the understanding of Emotional Intelligence and the acceptance of it as a practical approach to management and leadership. Many business owners are resistant to the idea of Emotional Intelligence because they see it as a sign of weakness; that somehow the acknowledgement of emotions in their business life will sap their strength or they see it as a personal affront, that somehow their social skills are being questioned. The irony for those who do not understand EQ is that emotionally intelligent people are more assertive, exert more influence and appear to have a natural power. They are also far more resilient and able to deal with challenging relationships effectively creating better outcomes for all involved. So now is the time to recognise your emotional intelligence and its power to grow or slow your business.

About the author

Dene is the founder of I Want To Be, a personal development consultancy that specialises in helping business owners develop themselves so that they can grow their business. Dene has over 30 years' commercial, leadership and management experience, having held a number of director roles, and he has also founded a number of his own businesses. His first book, ResourcefulMe,  investigates the subject of resourcefulne

item.title: Expert interview: How to set big, fat, hairy goals!
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
How realistic are your goals? If you diligently follow the traditional SMART formula for setting goals then your goals are probably not big enough!! That is the conclusion that BizClub interviewee David Hyner of Stretch Development came to after interviewing over 100 top achievers who are all creating amazing levels of success. In this recording Richard White interviews David on how to set MASSIVE goals and in particular, the 5 step model he developed by boiling down all the wisdom generated from his research into an easy to follow process he calls ‘The MASSIVE Goal Principle’. The five steps are: Step 1 – Set a big fat hairy goal!! Step 2 – Research your goal and break down into tasks Step 3 – Prioritise tasks and integrate into your daily calendar Step 4 – Take action! Step 5 – Never give up (Keep on keeping on!) By listening to this audio you will begin to understand the power of the 5 step model and how to take it from theory into action. It will get you thinking bigger and give you a structure for turning your big fat hairy goals into tangible results. We challenge you to follow David’s insights and not get inspired! Once you have listened to this audio we promise you that you will never settle for realistic goals again! You may want to listen to this more than once. If you get a chance then take notes. Although it is delivered in an easy to digest fashion it is packed with practical ideas. [audio mp3="http://hzhapr15a.dmclub.net/personaldevelopment/wp-content/uploads/sites/6/2015/03/davidhyner3.mp3"][/audio] To download - right click here as select 'Save As'

About David Hyner

David is an International professional speaker, trainer and workshop facilitator specialising individuals and teams to increase personal effectiveness. he is the founder of the MASSIVE goal principle which is based on over 4 years research of over 100 top achievers and their personal goal setting strategies.
